–ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ù–´–ï –ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü–´:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:


üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

(file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Diagnosing TypeScript inference error**

The error likely stems from TypeScript misinferring the generator yield type in `Effect.gen`, possibly due to older TS versions or IDE plugins; adding an explicit type annotation to the `result` variable should prevent the TS complaint and fix IDE lint errors.

**Planning precise type annotation**

Annotating `result` explicitly should fix TS7022, but due to `apiClient.GET` being a generic overload, `ReturnType` may yield overly broad types; considering using imported helper types to define a precise success type or restructuring to avoid the self-referential error by mapping inside the generator.

```typescript
      Effect.provide(MockMessageRepository),
      Effect.provide(MockNotificationService),
      Effect.tap((messageId) =>
        Effect.sync(() => {
          expect(messageId).toEqual(expectedMessageId)
        })
      ),
      Effect.asVoid
    )
  )
})
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/openapi-effect/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

```typescript
  Effect.gen(function* (_) {
```

6. **PROOF-–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–°–¢–í–ê –í PR**:

```markdown
## –ú–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–∏

### –ò–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç—ã:

### –ü–æ—Å—Ç—É—Å–ª–æ–≤–∏—è:
```

**Analyzing TypeScript error cause and mitigation**

The TS7022 error likely stems from inferred types on `yield*` expressions with `apiClient` calls; using explicit typing on these variables can prevent IDE errors despite no `tsc` issues. I'll try adding explicit type annotations to the `yield*` results to resolve the error without complicating code flow.

**Defining explicit success type aliases**

I'll create explicit type aliases for successful API responses using core types to annotate `result` variables, importing only types to avoid value overhead. This ensures clear, repeatable typings that prevent TS7022 without type assertions, supporting consistent and safe type usage.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`

- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:


### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Clarifying type namespace usage**

The `Effect` import is a merged namespace and value where `Effect.Effect` is a type (interface), and `Success` is nested under the `Effect` namespace, so `Effect.Success` is the correct type reference, not `Effect.Effect.Success`.

**Verifying correct Success type usage**

Confirmed `Effect.Success` is the right form since `Effect.Effect` is an interface, not a namespace; I'll search the repo for uses of `.Success<` with `Effect` to verify consistent usage.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/openapi-effect/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

**Defining explicit success type aliases**

I'm creating explicit type aliases for API success responses using `ApiSuccess` combined with path- and method-specific utility types to ensure accurate and maintainable typing for each API call, planning to annotate the yielded results accordingly while considering adding functional doc comments.

**Planning import reorder and formatting fixes**

I'm preparing to reorder imports by placing type specifiers before value imports to align with formatting expectations, removing unused imports, fixing property accesses, and considering adding minimal doc comments near the new effect changes.

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:

```typescript
// CHANGE: <–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∫–æ–µ –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è>

// SOURCE: <—Å—Å—ã–ª–∫–∞ —Å –¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–æ–π —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–æ–π –∏–∑ –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–µ–≥–æ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞> | n/a

// COMPLEXITY: O(time)/O(space) - –≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å
```

3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript
/**
```

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.

- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):

  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.

- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

–¶–ï–õ–¨: –°–æ–∑–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏ –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—É—é –ø–∞—Ä–∞–¥–∏–≥–º—É —Å –ø–æ–ª–Ω—ã–º —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã—Ö –≤—ã—á–∏—Å–ª–µ–Ω–∏–π –∏ –∫–æ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–ª–∏—Ä—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤.

–ú–û–î–ï–õ–¨ –†–ê–°–°–£–ñ–î–ï–ù–ò–Ø:

  (–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä Effect/FP, —Ä–µ–≤—å—é–µ—Ä —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤, —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∂ CORE‚ÜîSHELL, —Ç–µ—Å—Ç-–∏–Ω–∂–µ–Ω–µ—Ä).

  –ø–æ –∫—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—è–º –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–æ–≤, —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤–æ–π –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –∏ —Ç–µ—Å—Ç–∏—Ä—É–µ–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏ (–µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å —è–≤–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–æ—Å–∏—Ç –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä ‚Äî –≤—ã–±—Ä–∞—Ç—å –∏ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å).

–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–û –ü–†–û–¶–ï–°–°–ê (–ù–ï –§–û–†–ú–ê–¢ –û–¢–í–ï–¢–ê):

–õ—é–±–æ–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–∞—Ö, –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —Å–≤–æ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∞—Ö –∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä—è–µ–º—ã—Ö –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞—Ö. –ö–æ–¥ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞–Ω–∏—è –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—ã –∏ –ø–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–µ–Ω–∏—è –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–π –º–æ–¥–µ–ª–∏.

–ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ù–´–ï –ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü–´:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/openapi-effect/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Clarifying dprint's import sorting behavior**

Dprint formats code but generally doesn‚Äôt reorder import declarations; however, it may reorder named specifiers within imports‚Äîsuch as grouping `type` imports first‚Äîdepending on config. The import order error likely comes from such specifier sorting expectations in the current dprint config.

**Planning refactor to handle imports and effect error handling**

The dprint import order error can be fixed by matching specifier order as shown in the expected output. For error handling, I'll replace the async main with an effect pipeline catching defects and logging via `Console.error`. Adding `Cause` to imports enables `Cause.pretty` for clearer error messages while removing unused `Exit`. This keeps imports clean and aligns with lint rules.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills

(file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Deciding on logging and type annotations**

Decided to log errors using `Console.error` with a string plus a pretty-printed cause to keep code simple and avoid lint issues. To fix the `result` type error, adding explicit type annotations on the generator yield results will ensure proper typing without resorting to `any` or `unknown`.

**Defining precise API success types**

Planning to define explicit API success type aliases for each endpoint using generics from the `strict-types` module and use these for typed `result` declarations in generators to ensure safety and clarity. Next, I'll confirm the exact type names by inspecting the strict-types file.

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

```typescript
  Effect.gen(function* (_) {
```

6. **PROOF-–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–°–¢–í–ê –í PR**:

```markdown
## –ú–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–∏

### –ò–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç—ã:

### –ü–æ—Å—Ç—É—Å–ª–æ–≤–∏—è:
```

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

import type { HttpMethod, PathsWithMethod } from "openapi-typescript-helpers"

/**
 * Extract all paths that support a given HTTP method
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Result ‚äÜ paths
 */
export type PathsForMethod<
  Paths extends object,
  Method extends HttpMethod
> = PathsWithMethod<Paths, Method>

/**
 * Extract operation definition for a path and method
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant ‚àÄ path ‚àà Paths, method ‚àà Methods: Operation<Paths, path, method> = Paths[path][method]
 */
export type OperationFor<
  Paths extends object,
  Path extends keyof Paths,
  Method extends HttpMethod
> = Method extends keyof Paths[Path] ? Paths[Path][Method] : never

/**
 * Extract all response definitions from an operation
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 */
export type ResponsesFor<Op> = Op extends { responses: infer R } ? R : never

// ============================================================================
// Request-side typing (path/method ‚Üí params/query/body)
// ============================================================================

/**
 * Extract path parameters from operation
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Returns path params type or undefined if none
 */
export type PathParamsFor<Op> = Op extends { parameters: { path: infer P } }
  ? P extends Record<string, infer V> ? Record<string, V>
  : never
  : undefined

/**
 * Extract query parameters from operation
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Returns query params type or undefined if none
 */
export type QueryParamsFor<Op> = Op extends { parameters: { query?: infer Q } } ? Q
  : undefined

/**
 * Extract request body type from operation
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Returns body type or undefined if no requestBody
 */
export type RequestBodyFor<Op> = Op extends { requestBody: { content: infer C } }
  ? C extends { "application/json": infer J } ? J
  : C extends { [key: string]: infer V } ? V
  : never
  : undefined

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/openapi-effect/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

**Reviewing code formatting details**

I'm checking comment lines exceeding 120 characters to prevent dprint formatting errors, planning to manually wrap long comments since dprint's behavior on comment reflow is uncertain.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:

```typescript
// CHANGE: <–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∫–æ–µ –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è>

// SOURCE: <—Å—Å—ã–ª–∫–∞ —Å –¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–æ–π —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–æ–π –∏–∑ –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–µ–≥–æ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞> | n/a

// COMPLEXITY: O(time)/O(space) - –≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å
```

3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript
/**
```

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è

- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

**Adjusting code to fix dprint extra line break errors**

The extra line breaks around some `Effect.catchTag` calls cause dprint complaints; I'll reformat these calls to single lines matching existing style since they fit within line length limits.

**Inlining specific catchTag and catchAllCause calls**

I'll convert flagged multi-line `Effect.catchTag("UnexpectedContentType", ‚Ä¶)` and `Effect.catchAllCause` calls into single lines to comply with dprint's formatting rules.

*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: packages/app/examples/strict-error-handling.ts
@@
-  Effect.catchTag("UnexpectedContentType", (e) =>
-    Console.log(`Unexpected content-type: ${e.actual ?? "unknown"}`)),
+  Effect.catchTag("UnexpectedContentType", (e) => Console.log(`Unexpected content-type: ${e.actual ?? "unknown"}`)),
@@
-  Effect.catchTag("UnexpectedContentType", (e) =>
-    Console.log(`Unexpected content-type: ${e.actual ?? "unknown"}`)),
+  Effect.catchTag("UnexpectedContentType", (e) => Console.log(`Unexpected content-type: ${e.actual ?? "unknown"}`)),
@@
-  Effect.catchTag("UnexpectedContentType", (e) =>
-    Console.log(`Unexpected content-type: ${e.actual ?? "unknown"}`)),
+  Effect.catchTag("UnexpectedContentType", (e) => Console.log(`Unexpected content-type: ${e.actual ?? "unknown"}`)),
@@
 const program = mainProgram.pipe(
   Effect.provide(FetchHttpClient.layer),
-  Effect.catchAllCause((cause) =>
-    Console.error(`Unexpected defect: ${Cause.pretty(cause)}`))
+  Effect.catchAllCause((cause) => Console.error(`Unexpected defect: ${Cause.pretty(cause)}`))
 )
*** End Patch

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/openapi-effect/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

## Skills

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:


3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript

 *
```

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

Modifications were made in `packages/app/examples/strict-error-handling.ts`. Verification was done with `npx eslint examples/strict-error-handling.ts` (noting a non-blocking baseline-browser-mapping warning) and `npx tsc --project packages/app/tsconfig.json --noEmit --pretty false`. Next steps can include running full lint or tests via `npm run lint` or `npm test` if desired. SOURCE: n/a

payload.message:
Updated the strict error handling example to satisfy the reported lint/TS issues: reordered imports per dprint, added explicit success-type aliases to avoid implicit-any in generator yields, guarded optional content-type strings, and removed the async/await entrypoint by handling defects inside Effect and running with `void Effect.runPromise` in `packages/app/examples/strict-error-handling.ts`.

- Fixed: import order + type specifier order, `string | undefined` template usage, and async/await + floating promise violations in `packages/app/examples/strict-error-handling.ts`
- Added: explicit success type aliases tied to OpenAPI operations in `packages/app/examples/strict-error-handling.ts`
- Adjusted: defect handling to `Effect.catchAllCause` and `void Effect.runPromise` in `packages/app/examples/strict-error-handling.ts`

Verification:
- `npx eslint examples/strict-error-handling.ts` (passes; only warning about baseline-browser-mapping data being stale)
- `npx tsc --project packages/app/tsconfig.json --noEmit --pretty false`

Next steps (optional):
1) Run full lint suite: `npm run lint` from repo root.
2) Run tests: `npm test`.
